Title: Year of embracing curiosity
Description: Resolutions don’t work. Though it may be limited to my own social bubble, it seems like most people have come to this same conclusion. What does seem to work, though, is themes. You choose a theme and use it as a guiding principle for the countless decisions you’ll face throughout the year.This will be my 4th year of using the theme-based resolution method. I usually take the holiday break to think about what sort of theme would truly make a difference in my life were I to focus on it for a whole year. For the past two weeks, I’ve thought deeply about this and have come up with my theme:Year of embracing curiosityTo those unfamiliar with this method, it may seem oddly vague. The absence of metrics, accountability, or even a clear goal makes it feel like just another sentence. But this is the whole point of a theme: the antithesis of the familiar disappointment that typical resolutions bring – a guiding light on the unbeaten path of a new year.So, why this theme? Phrases like “I just don’t understand,” “that’s over my head,” or “I’m not smart enough for this” have always left a bitter taste in my mouth. Yet, I often find myself relying on them. I’ve denied myself knowledge with the underlying notion that my brain wasn’t wired to understand certain things.Over the last decade, I’ve done away with certain phrases that I didn’t want to be associated with anymore:- I’m bored- I’m lazy- I regret xyzI don’t say these anymore – ever. Phrases like that carve the version of you that exists in your head. This year, I’ll be discontinuing any phrases hinting at an aversion to embracing curiosity. Instead, when I come across something unfamiliar or daunting in complexity, I want to approach it with curiosity. I want to ask more questions about it, do research, and maybe even master a few topics.I’m starting 2025 by learning Vim – an open-source method for editing text and code. It’s something that I always found intimidating due to its complexity and steep learning curve, but I’m already 2 weeks in and getting the hang of it. Throughout the year, I plan on tackling other things that I found to be too hard for me to understand or master. Things such as higher-level math, C (programming language), kickboxing, the tax code, and sales.With enough time and effort, anything can be learned.2025 - Year of embracing curiosity2024 - Year of dedicated focus2023 - Year of leap of faith2022 - Year of travel

Title: Real-Time User Experience Will Define the Future of Software
Description: Discover how the web is evolving past outdated, one-directional interactions and embracing the demand for real-time experiences. This blog post delves into the current shortcomings of user engagement, the root causes of our craving for immediacy, and innovative examples from the tech world, like Anduril and ChatGPT, that illustrate the shift towards a more dynamic, engaging online landscape. Join the conversation about the future of web experiences—where real-time interactivity isn't just desirable; it's essential.

Title: Async I/O Is Not Enough
Description: For the past few months, I’ve been exploring Go. Having done quite a bit of grueling work shaving off milliseconds from Python web apps, I’ve found Go to be incredible. You can schedule dirt cheap concurrent operations — simply by adding go in front of a function call — and achieve true parallelism across cores.
